item.title: CXF-DOSGi 1.2 Has All the Tools for Distributed OSGi
item.description: The Distributed OSGi subproject of Apache CXF was released this week with a new reference implementation included for the Remote Service Admin (RSA) specification
item.dc:creator: mitchp
item.content:encoded: The Distributed OSGi subproject of Apache CXF was released this week with a new reference implementation included for the Remote Service Admin (RSA) specification

item.title: Servlet 3.0 – A spaghetti API?
item.description: The introduction in Servlet 3.0 of “web fragments” and both annotation-based and programmatic mechanisms for introducing components into a web-application are all very welcome.
item.dc:creator: jrandol
item.content:encoded: The introduction in Servlet 3.0 of “web fragments” and both annotation-based and programmatic mechanisms for introducing components into a web-application are all very welcome.

item.title: The Whyline for Java
item.description: Usually when we see something go wrong in a program's output, we have to guess what code is causing the problem. We usually guess wrong. The Whyline for Java allows you to instead ask questions about a program's output and get answers in terms of the code responsible.
item.dc:creator: Gene Gotimer
item.content:encoded: Usually when we see something go wrong in a program's output, we have to guess what code is causing the problem. We usually guess wrong. The Whyline for Java allows you to instead ask questions about a program's output and get answers in terms of the code responsible.

item.title: ASP.NET vs Ruby on Rails
item.description: James Avery has worked with ASP.NET for a long time, but recently he's fallen in love with Ruby on Rails. Rails is perfect for a 2-person startup like the one Avery runs.
item.dc:creator: lyndsey
item.content:encoded: James Avery has worked with ASP.NET for a long time, but recently he's fallen in love with Ruby on Rails. Rails is perfect for a 2-person startup like the one Avery runs.

item.content:encoded: This article tried to share with you a few points on how to make code reviews really effective.

item.content:encoded: Collection of 35 hand-picked innovative and fresh Illustrator tutorials ready for you to follow and pick up tons of new techniques.

item.title: Understanding Covariance and Contravariance
item.description: There are as many explanations, examples, and mathematical descriptions for covariance and contravariance as you care to explore, but all of this information adds to the confusion. This article shows you why they are important concepts for software developers and how you can leverage variance when you design your code.
item.dc:creator: HeyNow
item.content:encoded: There are as many explanations, examples, and mathematical descriptions for covariance and contravariance as you care to explore, but all of this information adds to the confusion. This article shows you why they are important concepts for software developers and how you can leverage variance when you design your code.

item.title: If you're an architect...
item.description: A simple link to a presentation and a great discussion on many architectural topics...join the conversation!
item.dc:creator: TheSiteMan
item.content:encoded: A simple link to a presentation and a great discussion on many architectural topics...join the conversation!

item.title: How programming checklists can save a lot of time and anguish
item.description: Airplane pilots are highly educated and trained individuals. Yet they have detailed checklists for most everything they do. Why? Because human beings are imperfect and mistakes can rapidly turn fatal in a plane. So they use the checklists and in doing so make flying much safer. Hospitals have recently started doing the same. Again medical personal are highly educated, yet they are fining instituting checklists recuduce complications and save lives. A lot of lives.
item.dc:creator: dt80257
item.content:encoded: Airplane pilots are highly educated and trained individuals. Yet they have detailed checklists for most everything they do. Why? Because human beings are imperfect and mistakes can rapidly turn fatal in a plane. So they use the checklists and in doing so make flying much safer. Hospitals have recently started doing the same. Again medical personal are highly educated, yet they are fining instituting checklists recuduce complications and save lives. A lot of lives.

item.content:encoded: New version of Exadel JavaFX Plug-in for Eclipse version 1.3.4 with Organize Imports feature

item.title: Bind Enum to a WPF ListBox using ObjectDataProvider
item.description: The Enum.GetValues() method retrieves an array of the values of the constants in an Enum. Let us see how to use this method and bind an Enumeration to a WPF ListBox using the ObjectDataProvider.
item.dc:creator: gracekolen
item.content:encoded: The Enum.GetValues() method retrieves an array of the values of the constants in an Enum. Let us see how to use this method and bind an Enumeration to a WPF ListBox using the ObjectDataProvider.

item.title: Find Maximum Value in each Row – SQL Server
item.description: Here’s a simple and efficient way to find the maximum value in each row using SQL Server UNPIVOT
item.dc:creator: gracekolen
item.content:encoded: Here’s a simple and efficient way to find the maximum value in each row using SQL Server UNPIVOT

item.title: Discovering Java Annotations
item.description: Annotations are proving to be widely popular these days. Many annotation-based frameworks (Spring, JPA, Tapestry to name few) are seeing the light of the day, and even small scale projects are using annotation based meta-programming for better separation of concerns. Annotations are wonderful and are sure to stay here.
item.dc:creator: jsugrue
item.content:encoded: Annotations are proving to be widely popular these days. Many annotation-based frameworks (Spring, JPA, Tapestry to name few) are seeing the light of the day, and even small scale projects are using annotation based meta-programming for better separation of concerns. Annotations are wonderful and are sure to stay here.

item.title: Whatever happened to Perl?
item.description: Once one of the pillars of the Internet, is Perl now fading away -- or will Perl 6 will spark a renaissance for the programming language?
item.dc:creator: mswatcher
item.content:encoded: Once one of the pillars of the Internet, is Perl now fading away -- or will Perl 6 will spark a renaissance for the programming language?

item.title: Ubuntu's two big advantages over Windows and Mac
item.description: I’ve been using the latest version (10.04) of Ubuntu Linux since April and there’s a lot to like about it. I announced earlier this year that I was giving desktop Linux another look, and I went with Ubuntu because it is the Linux distribution most focused on a desktop OS. I have lots of observations about the Ubuntu experience and how it compares to Mac and Windows, but I’m going to save most of that feedback for another article.
item.dc:creator: mswatcher
item.content:encoded: I’ve been using the latest version (10.04) of Ubuntu Linux since April and there’s a lot to like about it. I announced earlier this year that I was giving desktop Linux another look, and I went with Ubuntu because it is the Linux distribution most focused on a desktop OS. I have lots of observations about the Ubuntu experience and how it compares to Mac and Windows, but I’m going to save most of that feedback for another article.

item.title: ESB frameworks
item.description: A blog on introduction to ESB framework capabilities.
item.dc:creator: naveenb
item.content:encoded: A blog on introduction to ESB framework capabilities.

item.title: Avoiding Nulls with "Tell, Don't Ask" Style
item.description:
In the discussion group for Growing Object-Oriented Software, Guided by Tests Uberto Barbini wrote: "[I'm] not sure how to use "Tell, Don't Ask" for removing null reference[s]."
If an object has a query method that returns a value that might not exist, then it must have some way of returning the "does not exist" case.
item.dc:creator: piccoloprincipe
item.content:encoded: In the discussion group for Growing Object-Oriented Software, Guided by Tests Uberto Barbini wrote: "[I'm] not sure how to use "Tell, Don't Ask" for removing null reference[s]." If an object has a query method that returns a value that might not exist, then it must have some way of returning the "does not exist" case.

item.title: -2000 Lines Of Code
item.description: In early 1982, the Lisa software team was trying to buckle down for the big push to ship the software within the next six months. Some of the managers decided that it would be a good idea to track the progress of each individual engineer in terms of the amount of code that they wrote from week to week. They devised a form that each engineer was required to submit every Friday, which included a field for the number of lines of code that were written that week.
item.dc:creator: mitchp
item.content:encoded: In early 1982, the Lisa software team was trying to buckle down for the big push to ship the software within the next six months. Some of the managers decided that it would be a good idea to track the progress of each individual engineer in terms of the amount of code that they wrote from week to week. They devised a form that each engineer was required to submit every Friday, which included a field for the number of lines of code that were written that week.

item.title: jBPM 4.4 is live
item.description: The wait was long yet worth the while. jBPM 4.4 is now available for download. This new version resolves nothing short of 108 issues including feature requests and bugs. Compared to v4.3, with 47 issues, and v4.2, with 40, this release is a double pack.
item.dc:creator: mitchp
item.content:encoded: The wait was long yet worth the while. jBPM 4.4 is now available for download. This new version resolves nothing short of 108 issues including feature requests and bugs. Compared to v4.3, with 47 issues, and v4.2, with 40, this release is a double pack.

item.title: SQL Server - CAST vs CONVERT
item.description: This post explains the differences between CAST and CONVERT functions in SQL Server.
item.dc:creator: jacobsebastian
item.content:encoded: This post explains the differences between CAST and CONVERT functions in SQL Server.

item.title: Project Lombok - Java Without the Boilerplate
item.description: This article details how to use Project Lombok and it's bytecode generation magic to remove so much standard boilerplate from Java classes.
item.dc:creator: HamletDRC
item.content:encoded: This article details how to use Project Lombok and it's bytecode generation magic to remove so much standard boilerplate from Java classes.

item.title: JavaFX Revisited: Moving Forward
item.description: One of the most popular polls we've had on JavaLobby recently was based around the future of JavaFX. The poll started a healthy discussion covering different perspectives on that state of JavaFX. From the poll choices, most people went along with the idea that Oracle should give up on JavaFX. The success of HTML5 makes many question whether there is a need for RIA technologies such as JavaFX, Flash and Silverlight anymore. The next most popular choice was for Oracle to open source JavaFX.
item.dc:creator: jsugrue
item.content:encoded: One of the most popular polls we've had on JavaLobby recently was based around the future of JavaFX. The poll started a healthy discussion covering different perspectives on that state of JavaFX. From the poll choices, most people went along with the idea that Oracle should give up on JavaFX. The success of HTML5 makes many question whether there is a need for RIA technologies such as JavaFX, Flash and Silverlight anymore. The next most popular choice was for Oracle to open source JavaFX.

item.title: A tutorial on Remote Procedure Calls (RPCs) in Google Web Toolkit
item.description: I wrote a short-ish tutorial on how to use RPCs in GWT. Sample code available to download.
item.dc:creator: hebejebelus
item.content:encoded: I wrote a short-ish tutorial on how to use RPCs in GWT. Sample code available to download.

item.title: WordPress › News » PHP 4 and MySQL 4 End of Life Announcement
item.description: Our approach with WordPress has always been to make it run on common server configurations. We want users to have flexibility when choosing a host for their precious content. Because of this strategy, WordPress runs pretty much anywhere. Web hosting platforms, however, change over time, and we occasionally are able to reevaluate some of the requirements for running WordPress. Now is one of those times. You probably guessed it from the title — we’re finally ready to announce the end of support for PHP 4 and MySQL 4!
item.dc:creator: @thierry_lefort
item.content:encoded: Our approach with WordPress has always been to make it run on common server configurations. We want users to have flexibility when choosing a host for their precious content. Because of this strategy, WordPress runs pretty much anywhere. Web hosting platforms, however, change over time, and we occasionally are able to reevaluate some of the requirements for running WordPress. Now is one of those times. You probably guessed it from the title — we’re finally ready to announce the end of support for PHP 4 and MySQL 4!

item.title: Daily Dose - DTrace Co-inventor Leaves Oracle
item.description: Bryan Cantrill, the co-inventor of DTrace, left Oracle recently. IBM could be losing money if the new EU probe finds unlawful tactics in the mainframe market.
item.dc:creator: mitchp
item.content:encoded: Bryan Cantrill, the co-inventor of DTrace, left Oracle recently. IBM could be losing money if the new EU probe finds unlawful tactics in the mainframe market.
